newsitem.title: GREECE: ATHLETICS-SUZUKI CONQUERS GRUELLING COURSE FOR MARATHON GOLD.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-SUZUKI CONQUERS GRUELLING COURSE FOR MARATHON GOLD.

text.p: Hiromi Suzuki continued Japan's modern mastery of the marathon by winning the world women's gold medal on Saturday on the ancient course from Marathon to Athens.

Suzuki, 26, competing in only her third marathon, clocked two hours 29 minutes 48 seconds over the traditional course covered by the Greek messenger Phidippides in 490 B.C. and used for the first Olympics of modern times in 1896.
She finished well clear of defending champion Manuela Machada of Portugal, who took the silver in 2:31:12 and Romanian Lidia Simon who clocked 2:31:55.

Suzuki accelerated away from the field around 26 kms on the hilliest and most gruelling part of the course, and was never in any trouble on the downhill section of the race, coming home alone at the Panathinaikon Stadium in Athens city centre, the venue for the 1896 Games.
Olympic champion Fatuma Roba of Ethiopia, the pre-race favourite and one of the leaders for the first 21 kms, suddenly dropped out of contention at that point and failed to finish.
Suzuki's victory follows Junko Asari's win at the Stuttgart world championships in 1993. Hiromi Taniguchi won the men's title in Tokyo in 1991.
